headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: J.P. Morgan's Accounting Quirk
summary: An accounting rule caused an earnings reduction at J.P. Morgan Chase due to an increase in its debt's market value—the opposite side of the gain posted a quarter ago when the value of its debt fell.

headline: Giants' Secondary May Deserve More Credit
summary: Giants fans find happy parallels between this year's Giants team and the 2007 edition that won Super Bowl XLII. The main similarity is a ferocious pass rush, but the much-maligned secondary actually deserves a little more credit.

headline: Toyota Sees Hybrid Getting 53 MPG
summary: Toyota said its latest hybrid vehicle will boast an industry-leading 53 miles per gallon in city driving and sell for less than $19,000.

headline: U.S. Stocks Drop
summary: U.S. stocks fell, but squeaked out an advance for the week, as fears of a credit downgrade of several euro-zone countries added to disappointing results from J.P. Morgan Chase.

headline: Quinn Backs Compromise on Wage Bill
summary: New York City Council Speaker Christine Quinn said she will support a compromise that will not mandate higher wages for employees of businesses that move into real-estate projects developed with government subsidies.

headline: Jenkins: The Truth About Bain and Jobs
summary: Job creation and destruction are both relentless. The small difference between the two is what we call prosperity.

headline: Flights Resume to Volcano-Stricken Argentine Resort
summary: An Argentine airline on Friday made the first commercial flight to the Patagonian tourist resort of San Carlos de Bariloche in more than seven months since a massive volcanic eruption left the town largely isolated.

headline: Groups Challenge Recess Appointments
summary: In the first legal challenge to Obama's recess appointments, three groups asked a judge to rule on whether the president's appointments to the NLRB violate the U.S. Constitution.

headline: Lions Gate Acquires Summit
summary: Lions Gate acquired Summit in a cash-and-stock deal valued at $412.5 million that unites two of Hollywood's biggest independent film studios.

headline: Judge Denies Preliminary Injunction in Air India Case
summary: A federal judge Friday denied a U.S. airline group's request for a preliminary injunction to block a multibillion-dollar package of U.S.-backed loan guarantees for Boeing jetliners ordered by Air India.

headline: Stepping Out in Style
summary: Lee Miller's custom-made cowboy boots have been worn by Lyle Lovett, Tommy Lee Jones and Willie Nelson. among others. Below, a sampling of his designs.

headline: Cordray's Charm Offensive
summary: Now that he's head of the most powerful agency in American history, Mr. Cordray is trying hard to rebrand himself as a neutral, dispassionate regulator.

headline: Westlake Chemical Stalking Georgia Gulf
summary: Westlake Chemical disclosed an unsolicited offer to buy Georgia Gulf for about $1.03 billion.

headline: As Fears Ebb, Hedge Funds Dip Toes Back Into 'Macro' Bets
summary: After a gut-wrenching 2011, hedge funds are betting signs of improvement in financial markets will give traditional "macro" trades based on economic growth and inflation a better chance of paying off.

headline: Kodak Sues Fujifilm Over Patents
summary: Eastman Kodak filed a patent-infringement lawsuit against rival Fujifilm, the latest effort by the struggling U.S. imaging company to draw value from its intellectual-property portfolio.

headline: SBA Changes: A Deeper Look
summary: President Obama plans to consolidate six government departments and agencies, including the Small Business Administration.

headline: Ackman Meets Hurdle in Canadian Pacific Pursuit
summary: Canadian National Railway warned its former CEO to reconsider his interest in the top job at rival Canadian Pacific, marking the latest twist in a proxy fight between Canadian Pacific and activist investor Bill Ackman.

headline: U.S. Trade Gap Expands
summary: Signs are growing that the U.S. economy hasn't accelerated quite as much in recent months as many economists thought.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In Friday's pictures, Hindu women wade in the Ganges River, dock workers get a yacht in Scotland into ship shape, Brazilian slum residents get ready to defend their neighborhood from eviction orders and more.

headline: Photos of the Day: Jan. 13
summary: In today's pictures, Hindu women wade in the Ganges River, dock workers get a yacht in Scotland into ship shape, Brazilian slum residents get ready to defend their neighborhood from eviction orders and more.

headline: Disney Names Movie Marketing Chief
summary: Walt Disney named Ricky Strauss its new president of movie marketing, after his predecessor departed earlier this week after less than two years on the job.

headline: Former Dow Chemical Scientist Gets Five Years in Prison
summary: A former Dow Chemical scientist was sentenced to five years in federal prison after he was convicted last year of stealing trade secrets from Dow and selling them to companies in China.

headline: Oil Falls Further Below $100
summary: Crude-oil futures fell further under the $100-a-barrel mark on Friday, as worse-than-expected U.S. trade figures and jitters over a prospective euro-zone debt downgrade dimmed prospects for U.S. economic growth.

headline: Peru Tries to Appease Mine Protesters
summary: A government investment package in the poor Cajamarca region is aimed at placating protesters who have stalled a $4.8 billion Newmont Mining project and cast uncertainty over natural-resource investments in Peru.

headline: Treasurys Rally on Euro-Zone Downgrade Fears
summary: Treasurys advanced, driven by fears of imminent sovereign credit-rating cuts within the euro zone.

headline: Obama to Elevate SBA Chief
summary: The president said that he will elevate the head of the Small Business Administration to a cabinet-level position.

headline: Bond Yields Rise on Downgrade Fear
summary: Peripheral bond yields reversed early falls and moved sharply higher on news that several euro-zone countries could face an imminent ratings downgrade by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Nigeria Oil Workers Threaten to Join Strikes
summary: Nigeria's government will meet with unions Saturday to try to negotiate an end to a strike that is costing Africa's top oil producer an estimated $1 billion a day, as oil workers threatened to raise the stakes by joining the strikes and halting crude production.

headline: Alaska Hit With Heavy Snow
summary: The worst winter anyone can remember in Alaska has piled snow so high people can't see out the windows, kept a tanker in ice-choked waters from delivering fuel on time and turned snow-packed roofs into sled runs.

headline: Euro Sinks on Possible S&P Downgrade
summary: The euro tumbled to a fresh 16-month low against the dollar amid talk that Standard & Poor's is on the brink of downgrading several European countries.

headline: Trustee Sues Madoff Investors to Recover $187.5 Million
summary: The official recovering funds for Bernard Madoff's swindled investors is suing several international firms for a total of $187.5 million.

headline: U.S. to Cut Forces in Europe
summary: Defense officials will cut the permanent U.S. force in Europe to two brigades, part of the Pentagon's plan to trim its budget over the next year and refocus its attention on Asia and the Middle East.

headline: No Finale for Greek Debt Drama
summary: As the Greek economy suffers, more debt relief is almost certainly needed. A solution is vital not just for Greece but for the euro zone.

headline: Bank of Korea Holds Rate Steady
summary: South Korea's central bank kept its benchmark interest rate on hold for a seventh straight month and reiterated its intention to keep prices stable amid  risks posed by the sovereign-debt crisis in Europe.

headline: Peru Court Sentences Van der Sloot to 28 Years
summary: A Peruvian court sentenced Dutch citizen Joran Van der Sloot to a 28-year sentence in connection with the 2010 killing of a young Peruvian woman.

headline: Rupee Rises to Near Six-Week High
summary: The Indian rupee rose to a near six-week high against the U.S. dollar, driven by capital flows into local debt as a series of measures to attract foreign cash began to pay off.

headline: Apple, Linn Energy: Money Flow Leaders (AAPL, LINE)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Europe Stocks Ease
summary: European stock markets generally overcame their fears about an imminent credit downgrade of several euro-zone countries. Both the Stoxx Europe 600 and France's CAC 40 index edged down just 0.1%.

headline: The Romney Surge
summary: After months of being criticized for remaining stationary in the polls, White House hopeful Mitt Romney is finally getting the surge he's been waiting for.

headline: LightSquared Presses for Investigation
summary: LightSquared is seeking an investigation into a member of an industry advisory board that has been critical of the company's wireless broadband network.

headline: Economists Split Over Additional Fed Action
summary: Economists are divided on whether the Fed will take further action this year, as they forecast slow but steady improvement in economic growth and employment through 2012.

headline: Iraq Bolsters Security to Protect Shiite Pilgrims
summary: Iraq's Shiite-led government enacted security measures to protect Shiite Muslim pilgrims observing the high point of a religious holiday.  Meanwhile, car bombs targeted officials in the polarized city of Kirkuk.

headline: FCC to Review Sports Blackout Rules
summary: Federal regulators plan to consider dumping rules that require cable and satellite TV providers to black out sports games if local teams don't sell out their arenas or stadiums.

headline: Société Générale to Cut Staff in Asia
summary: French bank Société Générale is cutting people in its corporate and investment banking division in Asia, as it scales back in capital-intensive areas.

headline: Prokhorov Fulfills Criteria for Vote
summary: Billionaire Nets basketball owner Mikhail Prokhorov's campaign said it has collected enough signatures to get on Russia's March presidential ballot.

headline: Asian Stocks Climb
summary: Mainland Chinese stocks, which tumbled after data showed a drop in foreign-exchange reserves, were a notable exception to a mostly higher day in Asia. The Nikkei gained 1.4%.

headline: U.S. Opens Diamond Foods Inquiry
summary: Federal prosecutors in San Francisco have opened an inquiry into whether financial practices at Diamond Foods involved criminal fraud, people familiar with the matter said.

headline: Email With Your Eyeballs, Change Channels With Your Spleen
summary: Reply to All Sums Up the Consumer Electronics Show

headline: EU Weighs Timing of Iran Oil Embargo
summary: An EU embargo on Iranian oil could be enacted after a six-month grace period under one of the options being considered, but there is still no consensus on the matter, Brussels diplomats said.

headline: Lawsuit Says Walgreen, Par Pharma Overcharged
summary: A union benefits fund filed a class-action lawsuit against Walgreen and Par Pharmaceutical, accusing the companies of engaging in "at least two widespread schemes to overcharge" for generic drugs.

headline: Slot Maker IGT to Buy Facebook Casino
summary: Slot-machine maker International Game Technology said it will acquire the  company behind a Facebook-based casino game for up to $500 million.

headline: Japan's Noda Shuffles Cabinet
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda picked a ruling party heavyweight known as a fiscal hawk as his deputy and removed two gaffe-prone ministers from their posts as part of a mini Cabinet reshuffle.

headline: Japan Plays Down Pledge to Cut Iran Oil Imports
summary: Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda said Tokyo will hold talks with U.S. officials before deciding on cuts in Iran oil imports, backing down from his finance minister's comments that Japan was ready to do so immediately.

headline: Taiwan Campaign Office Stormed
summary: Police arrested a woman who stormed into the campaign office of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party armed with a knife. No injuries were reported.

headline: Goldman Lifts Oil Forecasts
summary: Goldman Sachs raised its oil price forecasts as it shrugged off the influence of tensions between Iran and the West and cited more positive near-term economic developments in the U.S. and China and the reduced risk of contagion from Europe.

headline: ING May Sell More Assets
summary: Dutch financial-services company ING Groep may have to sell more assets to repay state aid, as it grapples to meet stricter banking rules and protect itself against choppy markets.

headline: Tesco's Super Market Meltdown
summary: Tesco's "Big Price Drop" wasn't meant to affect its shares, which slumped 16% Thursday. That may prove to be an overreaction, but investor confidence could be hard to regain.

headline: Spanish Inflation Slows
summary: Spanish inflation slowed in December to its lowest level in more than a year on falling energy prices, a rare piece of positive news for the euro zone's fourth-largest economy.

headline: A Scrappy New Year for U.K. Retailers
summary: Tesco's profit warning Thursday cast a shadow over the U.K. retail industry. Though other indicators give a less bleak picture of Christmas trading, investors shouldn't raise their hopes for 2012.

headline: Fires, Kites and Sun Worship
summary: Bonfires will be lit in north India for Lohri festival, while colorful kites will dot the sky as Makar Sankranti approaches. Some snapshots.

headline: Infosys Sticks to Hedging Stance
summary: Software exporter Infosys expects the Indian rupee to resume its downtrend against the U.S. dollar and is therefore sticking to its policy of keeping currency hedges light.

headline: India Tribunal Asks Ministry to Refund Telecom Penalties
summary: India's telecommunications tribunal overturned the Department of Telecommunications' decision to levy penalties on some telecom companies for delays in rolling out services, and ordered it to refund the fines it had already collected.

headline: India Shares Edge Up
summary: Indian shares gained, underpinned by improved risk sentiment that also sent Asian and European bourses higher.

headline: Jet Airways Converts Option for 17 Boeing Planes
summary: Jet Airways has exercised an option to buy 17 single-aisle 737-800 planes from Boeing, a senior executive at India's largest airline by market share said.

headline: Economic Adviser: India Economy to Grow 7.0%-7.5% this Year
summary: The Indian economy has been hurt by the continuing troubles in the global economy and will likely grow 7.0%-7.5% in the current fiscal year, Chief Economic Adviser Kaushik Basu said.

headline: Euro Zone Posts Trade Surplus
summary: A surge in exports helped the euro zone post a major surplus on trade with the rest of the world in November, an unexpected development that could boost hopes that the region will avoid a severe economic downturn.

headline: Peking im iPhone-Fieber
summary: Zum Verkaufsstart des neuen iPhone 4S harrten hunderte hoffnungsfrohe Chinesen über Nacht vor dem Apple-Store in Peking aus. Dann blieb der Laden dicht. Die Emotionen kochten über.

headline: Accounting Quirk Lurks for Banks
summary: U.S. banks listed billions of dollars in paper gains on derivatives last quarter due to an accounting rule that now could work against them—and their stock prices—as earnings season gets under way.

headline: Europe Holds Off on Stress Test
summary: The European Banking Authority will not conduct another stress test until the second half of the year at the earliest.

headline: Forex Gains Boost SNB's Coffers
summary: The Swiss National Bank said it expects a profit of about $13.8 billion for 2011, suggesting its capping of the Swiss franc against the euro boosted the value of its foreign-currency holdings.

headline: Southeast Asia in Pictures
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim was acquitted, hundreds of orangutans were evacuated in Indonesia, and the Myanmar government and one of the country's leading ethnic rebel groups signed a cease-fire.

headline: U.K. Data Suggest Falling Inflation
summary: Prices charged by U.K. companies at the factory gate registered their first monthly fall for a year and a half, reinforcing expectations that inflation is poised to slow sharply.

headline: Russia's Capital Flight Intensifies
summary: Capital flight from Russia more than doubled last year amid European sovereign debt worries and political instability at home, with an estimated $84.2 billion leaving the country.

headline: ECB Deposits Again Hit Record High
summary: Euro-zone banks' overnight deposits with the European Central Bank hit yet another all-time high, likely reflecting continued funding pressures in the banking sector.

headline: Apple Beijing Store Pelted With Eggs
summary: Apple fans in Beijing put their enthusiasm for the company's latest iPhone on display on Friday morning: They queued up the night before, pelted an Apple Store with eggs and chased down what appeared to be a mall employee.

headline: Japan Car Sales' Tricky Gear Shift
summary: Japan's automobile industry wants to watch a dismal 2011 for domestic sales disappear in the rear-view mirror.

headline: Coal India Workers Set for Wage Hike
summary: Coal India has agreed in-principle to increase the wages of its about 365,000 workers by 25%, a move that will increase its annual staff cost by roughly 40 billion rupees ($773 million), a company executive said.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: The 150th anniversary of a famous philosopher's birth, skiers in Gulmarg, children collect alms in the Ganges basin, Yoko Ono in New Delhi, and more.

headline: Korean Sovereign Wealth Fund Gets China QFII Nod
summary: Sovereign wealth fund Korea Investment Corp. said it has acquired a license to invest in Chinese securities, paving the way for the firm to further diversify its portfolio through purchases of Chinese Class A shares and bonds as early as this year.

headline: JK Lakshmi to Expand Capacity
summary: India's JK Lakshmi Cement plans to invest 20 billion rupees ($386 million) next financial year to set up new plants and expand production capacity, as it bets on the current phase of sluggish demand to abate in the long term.

headline: A New Condiment for the Modern Family
summary: Last year, Nick Loeb, the son of John L. Loeb, the former Ambassador to Denmark under President Reagan, launched a sort of unusual business: a crispy topping called Loeb's Onion Crunch.

headline: A Filmmaker Finds a Clear Voice in the Headlines
summary: Gerardo Naranjo is one of the most promising new talents to emerge from Mexico in the last decade. His latest effort, the narcotics thriller, "Miss Bala," catapults him into risky new territory.

headline: Two Sides of the Same Coin
summary: The Fondation Henri Cartier-Bresson's latest show, "Henri Cartier-Bresson / Paul Strand / Mexique 1932-1934," is a marvellous chance to compare and contrast the work of these two genius shutterbugs.

headline: Sundance: Hollywood Goes Hunting in the Hills
summary: Movies with Chris Rock, Elizabeth Olsen, Catherine Zeta-Jones and Richard Gere are seeking distribution.

headline: Books for Jewelry Collectors
summary: Jewelry collectors have a selection of three new books out to captivate their attention, from Fritz Falk's "Snake Jewellery from around the World" and Eric Knowles's "Lalique" to Rachel Church's "Rings."

headline: Stocks Manage to Outrun Bad Data
summary: Stocks finished slightly higher as investors shrugged off three tepid readings on the state of the U.S. economy and focused on the coming rush of corporate earnings headlines.

headline: Coke, Pepsi Try to Ease O.J. Fears
summary: Coca-Cola said it has been contacted by a "relatively small number" of consumers with questions about an unapproved fungicide found in orange juice sold by it and competitors in the U.S.

headline: Jonathan Macey: How Private Equity Works
summary: The alternative to the leaner, smaller firms created by private equity are bankrupt firms that don't employ anybody.

headline: Flaherty and Whitaker: Tim Tebow's Role Model
summary: In Danny Wuerffel, the star quarterback had an example of both religious and athletic devotion.

headline: More Spending Isn't What Schools Need
summary: In support of her state's Supreme Court ruling ordering more spending on public schools, Washington Gov. Christine Gregoire claims that without ample funds it's difficult for our students to compete effectively in today's global economy (U.S. News, Jan. 7).

headline: City Has Say on Aqueduct
summary: The New York City mayor's office has control over a significant swath of New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's plan to develop the nation's largest convention center in Queens, according to city planning records.

headline: Governor Cautioned Fed About Mortgages
summary: Former central-bank board member Susan Bies repeatedly expressed worries in Fed meetings about risks to consumers and banks from the housing bubble.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are today's top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: The Art of Directing a Fight Scene
summary: Steven Soderbergh on his coming movie "Haywire," starring Gina Carano, a professional mixed-martial-arts fighter with limited prior acting experience, in the lead role as an international black-ops agent.

headline: CBS in Talks on Letterman Contract
summary: CBS is in talks with David Letterman to renew the late-night TV host's contract, which had been set to expire later this year, potentially removing a big question mark hanging over the network's late-night lineup.

headline: Democrats Top GOP in 2011 Donations
summary: President Obama's re-election campaign, combined with the Democratic National Committee, brought in $244 million in 2011, giving the president a head start over the eventual Republican presidential nominee.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: A bolt of lightning hits a building in Jakarta, health officials cull birds to prevent the spread of bird flu in India, people queue up the night before Apple releases its iPhone 4S in China and more.

headline: Store Credit Used In Identity Thefts
summary: Federal and New York state prosecutors said Thursday more than 180 people with credit-card accounts at big-box retailers such as Home Depot Inc. and Sears Holdings Corp. had their information stolen in an identity-theft scheme.

headline: Memo: Steps Taken By Obama Are Legal
summary: The White House released a Justice Department opinion buttressing its contention that Obama's recess appointments of several officials was constitutional.

headline: A Chance to Be a Ready-for-Prime-Time Player
summary: This weekend, singer Lana Del Rey will give just her third live performance in the U.S.—on the stage of "Saturday Night Live."

headline: Mayor Aims at Teachers Union
summary: Mayor Bloomberg aimed squarely at the teachers union with proposals to reward the best educators with a $20,000 salary boost and bypass labor in an ongoing battle over evaluations.

headline: Appetite for (Creative?) Destruction
summary: Dueling images of the private-equity industry have come into stark relief, as  it has emerged as an issue in the presidential campaign. Industry participants—and some critics—say there is truth to both perspectives.

headline: New York Photos of the Week: Jan. 6 - 13
summary: A subway ride with no pants, Occupy Wall Street protesters take shelter in churches, boiling bagels and more.

headline: A Hotelier's New York Bachelor Pad
summary: Vikram Chatwal's two-story, 4,000 square-foot condominium in a Gwathmey Siegel-designed complex features a traditional, dark interior.

headline: Sears Seeks to Calm Nerves
summary: Several lenders who finance small suppliers to Sears and Kmart say they are pushing for more timely financial information and faster payment terms as they grow worried about the struggling retailer's future.

headline: A Night of Pillow Talk
summary: At the D & D Building Wednesday, the interior designer Malcolm James Kutner unveiled his new project, a collaboration with the Italian fabric house, Fortuny: a new line of pillows.

headline: Rivals Eye American Airlines
summary: Potential buyers are circling American Airlines, weighing bids for its parent company that could place the storied but unprofitable carrier in the hands of a rival or a private-equity firm.

headline: Birds Do It, Bees Do It, Even Zebrafish Do It—Just Too Little
summary: In the race to find new medical treatments, research scientists have turned to the striped zebrafish. Although prized for their ability to reproduce in uncanny numbers, the scientists always need more.

headline: The Bain Capital Bonfire
summary: Romney has a good story to tell, if he's willing to tell it.

headline: Romney Backers, Rivals Spar Over Bain in Ads
summary: Romney and his supporters launched a more forceful response to rivals who are criticizing his business record and trying to blunt his momentum toward the Republican Party's presidential nomination.

headline: Mets' Wilpon: 'I Think We'll Be Fine'
summary: The embattled owner reiterated his desire to maintain majority control of the team and addressed the departure of Jose Reyes in his first extended public comments since last spring.

headline: Euro Zone Leaves Rates Unchanged
summary: The ECB left its key rate on hold at 1%, as the central bank's chief Mario Draghi noted signs of stabilizing business activity.

headline: Peugeot Open to Broader Alliances
summary: Peugeot would be interested in forging a deeper alliance with another automotive group, but there are no talks currently under way, France's largest car maker said.

headline: The Fist Bump That Baffled Football
summary: Was Woodson's peculiar nod to Nicks inappropriate? Or a rare sighting of NFL sportsmanship?

headline: Goldman Bids for Bad Bonds
summary: Goldman Sachs recently approached the New York Fed and offered to buy a multibillion-dollar bundle of risky mortgage bonds that the Fed acquired in the 2008 bailout of AIG.

headline: Contempt for the Constitution
summary: Justice invents a legal rationale for Obama appointments.

headline: Hosannas for the Court
summary: A unanimous ruling for religious freedom, and a rebuke to Obama.

headline: AMR Under Pressure to Preserve Pensions
summary: The head of the federal agency that oversees corporate pensions is ratcheting up pressure on the parent of American Airlines to preserve the pension plans of the airline's 130,000 workers and retirees as it seeks to restructure in bankruptcy court.

headline: Board Stands by Pepsi CEO
summary: PepsiCo's strategic review is unlikely to result in a breakup of the company or a rebuke of CEO Indra Nooyi but more marketing dollars are expected to flow into sodas, and cost cuts—including layoffs—are expected.

headline: Taliban Pinpoint Limits of U.S. Peace Effort
summary: The Taliban ruled out recognizing the Afghan Constitution or the "stooge Kabul administration" of Karzai, even as it opens negotiations with the U.S., underscoring the challenges faced by the budding peace effort.

headline: A Globe-Trotter's New York Pad
summary: The larger-than-life SoHo duplex of a hotelier and party-circuit fixture.

headline: Latin Food Enlivens Throgs Neck
summary: Throgs Neck, a wind-swept peninsula in the southeast Bronx, is an unlikely place for a celebrity Cuban chef to embark on his newest venture.

headline: Iran to Let In U.N. Atomic Inspectors
summary: Iran agreed to host a high-level team of United Nation's nuclear inspectors later this month, Western diplomats said, a surprise development that could help to curb building tensions with the West.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Jan. 13, 2012

headline: U.S. Attempts to Stem Video Outcry
summary: Pentagon officials went to lengths to avert damage to the U.S. war effort from a video that shows a group of Marines urinating on militants' corpses.

headline: From Butcher to Plate
summary: Move over, John Brown Smokehouse, there's a new barbecue joint in western Queens. Butcher Bar serves up local, natural meat in a chic but rustic space, a take on meat stores of yore.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Jan. 13, 2012

headline: Defying Artistic Boundaries
summary: Spanish artist Antoni Muntadas has helped create an approach to art that defies boundaries of all kinds, blending realism and Surrealism in visually arresting work.

headline: A Partners' Fight Erupts at Wynn
summary: A battle that erupted this week between Steve Wynn and a longtime business partner reveals turmoil within the casino mogul's global empire that could add to its challenges in the explosive Asian casino market.

headline: The Short List: New Kathleen Edwards Album, 'Voyageur'
summary: Plus, Athol Fugard's "The Road to Mecca" on Broadway, and Tilda Swinton in "We Need to Talk About Kevin."

headline: California Bullet Train's Top Official to Step Down
summary: The top official of California's troubled high-speed-rail project said he would step down amid a growing backlash over the state's $98.5 billion plan to build a bullet train connecting San Francisco with Southern California.

headline: Sadanand Dhume: India's Reformer Who Never Was
summary: The country is slowing as Manmohan Singh's government refuses to unshackle business.

headline: Texas-Size Test for Senate Contenders
summary: The race to succeed retiring U.S. Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas is emerging as a test of whether a grass-roots campaign can work in a state as vast and costly for candidates as Texas.

headline: What's On Around Europe
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to exhibitions, concerts and events across Europe.

headline: HBO Takes Its Money to the Track
summary: "Luck" has Dustin Hoffman, the "Degenerates" and fractious, thoroughbred producers.

headline: New Jersey Weddings May Go Vegas Style
summary: New Jersey is hoping to bring a little Las Vegas razzle-dazzle to Atlantic City with a law making it easier to get married on a whim.

headline: High-Priced Rail
summary: If a high-speed link between London and the North is such a great idea, why not let private investors take the risk?

headline: Parks Worker Charged With Hate Crime
summary: New York City police have arrested and charged a Parks Department employee in connection with a black baby doll that was found hanging from a noose in the department's Bronx headquarters.

headline: Nets Shoot Lights Out and Still Find a Way To Lose
summary: They shot 57% from behind the arc and made 20 threes Wednesday...and still, no win.
